moves.1. d4: N.B. I know, I should have played Black in this game, but I would rather not replay the game - I will compensate by playing Black in the next two games, how about that...
moves.1... d5 2. c4 c6: Fritz chooses the Slav Defence. I have little experience of this opening, but I think I can wing it somehow...
moves.3. Nf3 Nf6 4. Nc3 dxc4: I think this transposes into Queen's Gambit Accepted territory. Much more comfortable for me.
moves.5. e4 b5 6. a4: The classic move to undermine Black's queenside pawn structure in the QGA.
moves.6... b4: Bypassing my a-pawn, Fritz is squashing my queenside with his b- and c-pawns.
moves.7. e5: I realised that this loses me a pawn. But it was the best way to keep my queenside open.
Fritz demonstrates his tactical skill. He likes to have all my pieces nicely pinned to my king.
moves.12... Be6 13. Bxe6 Qxe6 14. Qxe6+ fxe6 1: This loses me the a-pawn. I realised that just after having made the move. But then, I can create counterplay by attacking the e-pawn...
moves.16... Nb6 17. Rfe1 Nxa4 18. Rxe6+ Kd7: Oh dear. I've blundered. Now I will lose either the rook or the bishop...for nothing.
moves.20... Bxe7:
And I resigned. Behind by a rook, a bishop and a passed pawn - how could this position get any worse!?

Anyway, after my shocking performance against Unleashed Fritz 10, at least I retain a slim lead over the Computers - the scores as they stand are 2.5 to fatcat2, 1.5 to the Computers.

I have learned from my mistakes. Never again will I muck up in this horrific way, against a computer or a human. And never again will I pile the brandy cream so high on the Christmas pudding...
